data.author: TheUmber
data.content: Here's the link and a summary from today's US State Department critical minerals meeting: state . gov/releases/office-of-the-spokesperson/2026/02/opening-remarks-of-the-critical-minerals-ministerial/  (remove spaces) The U.S. administration argues that critical mineral markets are distorted by overproduction, price volatility and non-market practices that discourage long-term investment. This has caused mining and processing projects worldwide to stall or fail, weakening supply chain resilience and threatening economic and security interests. The administration views this as a shared international problem that requires coordinated action among allies. To address this, the United States outlines a strategy centred on reindustrialisation, securing end-to-end supply chains and rebuilding domestic mining and processing capacity. Measures include large-scale public financing, direct investment in mining and processing projects, accelerated permitting, creation of strategic mineral stockpiles and protection of domestic producers from unfair price competition. A key proposal is the creation of a preferential critical minerals trade zone among allied countries, featuring enforceable price floors and coordinated trade measures to stabilise markets, support investment and prevent market flooding. The goal is to diversify global supply, ensure predictable pricing and strengthen partner economies while reducing dependence on concentrated or unreliable sources. Japan strongly supports these objectives, highlighting its own efforts to diversify supply, invest upstream and downstream and enhance economic security through legislation, public-private financing and international cooperation. Japan stresses that resilience can only be achieved collectively and welcomes new forums for coordination such as FORGE. U.S. officials further outline four pillars of action: investing in mining projects, stockpiling critical minerals, protecting producers from market distortions and rebuilding the mining ecosystem through regulatory reform and workforce development. The overarching message is a shift from discussion to execution, with the United States seeking broad international participation to build resilient, secure and diversified critical mineral supply chains that support long-term global prosperity and security.
data.thread_title: US State Department Critical Minerals Meeting

data.author: bandit1
data.content: SOLG was sold for a song ( assuming it completes) due to Newmont and BHP providing irrevocable undertakings at a level which shocked most LTH’s including me. In the end the control premium was modest as the larger holders bent over. Our directors have very modest holdings in OMI ( last time I looked I had more than our Chairman and CEO combined) so I suspect they are keen to maintain control for a number of years to monetize what looks like an attractive portfolio of opportunities. We have few large blocks last time I looked which could  be persuaded by the offer of a ‘modest’ premium like 40% when the journey is really just starting. Never say never but highly unlikely IMO that an offer  for the whole will be tabled at this stage as it would probably have to be hostile and could be well defended. Much more likely is a JV on El P and Brad is probably just waiting for the PM markets to calm down a little to release the MRE on Pepas which should show very impressive economics for a relatively modest capital commitment. Perhaps the BOD have received interest on both El P and El Cedro and have been discussing the optimum outcome along with ensuring that the structure of any JV with Newmont or Agnico will not come back to bite us as is sadly seen with too much frequency these days. I expect news this week either way.

data.author: velma
data.content: I don't know, Northman.  I spent a bit of time yesterday rewatching the presentations/interviews from late last year ( https://www.orosur.ca/investors/presentations/). The discussion re El Cedro at mins 6-10 in the November interview ( https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=E_ZnaIec-jw) went over my head at the time, but now seems like a clear statement from Brad that his strategy for 2026 is to try and find a big project that will attract someone like Newmont. As he says, Pepas isn't that project, but they pursued it to get the market support to get the money for exploration, which is exactly what OMI received in the last big raise.  That's why the APTA timeline has dragged, because they no longer need that MRE to get the share price up, so it's not a priority.  El Cedro is looking like a Q2 drill target rather than Q1, what with the aeromag delays, but Brad does seem to think it could be a million-ouncer, and that's why it's getting prioritised.  El Pantano, one hopes, might fall into the same category, but I think they know less about it at the moment.

data.author: Gourd
data.content: A Mineral Resource Estimate (MRE) is a technical assessment that calculates the tonnage and grade of a mineral deposit based on geological data (drilling, sampling, modeling) to determine its economic potential. It defines the size and quality of a deposit, typically categorized by confidence level (Measured, Indicated, Inferred) to guide mining projects and investment decision. Bottom line is we are after "measured (& indicated)" which should convert to bookable reserves as soon as feasibility studies are completed and final investment decisions are made to commence mining. Paper value assigned to each ounce gets closer to true value as the uncertainty reduces. Hoping minimum 100-200kOz  measured at >4g/t  to support current share price anything higher in the indicated and inferred is upside. Drill spacing looks close enough for measured across all of the main ore zone. GLA.

data.author: velma
data.content: Sanguine, Brad was saying on 24 Jan ( https://x.com/OrosurM/status/2014982783693697145) that re El Pantano "we have enough now to be getting some sort of picture of what we are seeing there.  Needs to be pulled together into a coherent story."  He's been stressing since drilling began that the goal was only to get a sense of the geology, rather than target the best hits.  They've rejigged how the assays are being tested, seemingly because they were seeing both gold and silver, so it seems unlikely the results are bad, and it's been confirmed that they found the sort of banding they were looking for.  The neutral case is that no one's had time to sit down and do the analysis on what the assays mean, and that's why they've not been released.  The hard bullish case is that they're already in talks about a JV or sale and the other party wants the results sat on.  That seems less likely, but either way, it's just a waiting game.

data.author: Kemot
data.content: I’ve been invested in explorers since 2018, and if there’s one rule of thumb, it’s that deadlines get missed over and over. I’ve heard that companies often provide timelines by essentially guessing the timeframe, because in many cases it’s impossible to know how long things will take. A rough deadline is often considered better than no deadline at all, otherwise investors might panic. Even the best explorers fail to deliver on on tume most of the time. I dont understand why so many of you pay such close attention to deadlines

data.author: Legalwolf
data.content: Have to agree with the Doc on this one.  This is most definitely not the time to sell and think those that due will come to rue it.  We are only in January and there is SO much exciting newsflow to come here during the rest of the year, regardless of the macros.  There is every chance that new discoveries will be announced and we are on the verge of such at El P and North Pepas.  We also have guaranteed world class drilling results to come from APTA, which is about to be drilled to MRE. So whether the share price goes up, down, or sideways on the MRE, it will sure as hell be bouncing towards new highs on the newsflow to come in the weeks and months ahead.  Of that I am very confident.  OMI appears to have the midas touch when it comes to its projects.  Pepas is the smallest but perhaps tastiest, but the big hitters are yet to come.  Have to be here when those projects start to come home and for the biggest gains. Do not give your shares away too cheaply or prematurely.  Many have done already, and are no doubt regretting bailing out too early. 40p is a level we should all be relatively comfortable with and remain firmly sitting on those hands.  But we've told many this already and folk will do what comes most easily to them.  All good and GLA for whatever you do around the MRE!

data.author: Legalwolf
data.content: Hi Doc - a lot will depend on exactly when those catalysts land.  Some of the relevant factors might be: 1) What is gold doing at the time the particular catalyst lands? 2) What is the general market doing? 3) What is OMI's share price doing - consolidating, retracing or already on the move up?  (FOMO, sell on news, etc) 4) Has there already been another catalyst recently delivered to the market? 5) What other catalysts or news is pending at that time? There's no doubt that a new discovery at Pepas North will be a biggie.  But I also think that getting "Pepas style" results at APTA will move the share price needle, especially if they land in favourable market conditions.  It goes without saying that the same applies at El Cedro (huge project).  As for El P, we will need to wait to see what they have already found, and how close they are to a major discovery there, when they will target the discovery, as well as what JV interest they get. But plenty of fantastic share price drivers here, which is what makes this a very exciting and compelling share.  If the Pepas MRE can take us and provide us with a higher floor (whether much higher or slightly higher), then it sets us up very nicely for one or more of the multiple potential catalysts that we have coming up here to then drive us up to the next level.  That's the investment case here and it's just a case of letting it play out over the coming months and quarters.  Let's hope we get off to a cracking start with the Pepas MRE.  All imo and GLA

data.author: ID78
data.content: Why does that mean a tie up with MTL? Are they nearby? Could they process the ore? I think it is clear that the plan is to get Pepas into production via toll payments in order to provide cash for drilling and cash to  fund the CAPEX of their own production plant but only IF they find a Columbia deposit big enough to justify that plant CAPEX.. There’s no doubt that is the plan….. that is why they went after PEPAS south first. Maybe not the biggest deposit but open pit mining, high grade deposit meaning low AISC. Near roads so it can be refined nearby using toll payments with low capex and so a quicker route to production (no plant to build and commission) and so a quick route to generating cash…. It’s just all so very …. Sensible

data.author: OrangeMoon
data.content: The solid investment case here is Pepas Deposit — a true golden nugget. High-grade (from surface), low-tonnage potential that should — all going well — return multiples of the current market cap. This will probably take 2–3 years to come to fruition and start delivering those returns. It's a great long-term investment case in my opinion. I think the institutional investors agree. It's often stated that "where there is gold, there is more"… and as Brad has said, "we've only just scratched the surface… we haven't even begun to look deep." Initially, I invested here because of Pepas and the potential for another deposit of this type. I haven't lost any optimism about the prospect of finding Pepas North — in fact, I've only grown more confident. So remember: regardless of the distractions caused by short-term price fluctuations (whether in the metals market or OMI's share price) and the emotions they may trigger for investors watching the hourly/daily/weekly charts, our deposits have been forming over millions of years… and just like me, they aren't going anywhere.

data.author: middleEastMoney
data.content: This applies to OMI I think. “Not exactly. Broadly speaking, as a gold prospect generator, that view might hold — but let me explain, because there are several factors at work. At the point where true value is first created — the “HAD005 moment”, when you actually discover gold — the share price is leveraged partly to the gold price and partly to market perception and expectations. At that stage, the share price reflects value in the ground, which itself depends on multiple new variables: size and grade how big the system is location and, critically, the realistic probability of becoming an economic mine Many projects fail. Many mines fail. Above all, however, the share price reflects the market’s confidence in management’s ability to deliver a mine or project. That’s precisely why GGP’s share price fell so hard while De Grey’s didn’t fall as badly in 2022. Once you become a gold producer, everything changes. The key difference is that you can now leverage your balance sheet and cash flow against both operational performance and the gold price. You’re no longer forced to rely on debt. You can: fund project development internally, accelerate projects , discover additional ounces, consolidate assets , acquire complementary projects In short, production gives you control — and that’s where sustained value creation really begins. GGP's SP exploded once it became clear GGP management had control. A wise and called Rusty Delroy once said 8 or 9 /10ths of any junior miner or developers value /market cap is essentially the market's confidence that they will deliver. This is easily demonstrated by Solgold was recently sold for £850m whereas GGP is today worth some £4.5bn and pumping out $ billions in revenue. But yet solgold had over 24moz of gold - versus GGPs 3 moz. Funny that don't you think. Serious investors (ie the market) felt Solg management were un-investable.”

data.author: TheUmber
data.content: Here's the link and a summary from today's US State Department critical minerals meeting: state . gov/releases/office-of-the-spokesperson/2026/02/opening-remarks-of-the-critical-minerals-ministerial/  (remove spaces) The U.S. administration argues that critical mineral markets are distorted by overproduction, price volatility and non-market practices that discourage long-term investment. This has caused mining and processing projects worldwide to stall or fail, weakening supply chain resilience and threatening economic and security interests. The administration views this as a shared international problem that requires coordinated action among allies. To address this, the United States outlines a strategy centred on reindustrialisation, securing end-to-end supply chains and rebuilding domestic mining and processing capacity. Measures include large-scale public financing, direct investment in mining and processing projects, accelerated permitting, creation of strategic mineral stockpiles and protection of domestic producers from unfair price competition. A key proposal is the creation of a preferential critical minerals trade zone among allied countries, featuring enforceable price floors and coordinated trade measures to stabilise markets, support investment and prevent market flooding. The goal is to diversify global supply, ensure predictable pricing and strengthen partner economies while reducing dependence on concentrated or unreliable sources. Japan strongly supports these objectives, highlighting its own efforts to diversify supply, invest upstream and downstream and enhance economic security through legislation, public-private financing and international cooperation. Japan stresses that resilience can only be achieved collectively and welcomes new forums for coordination such as FORGE. U.S. officials further outline four pillars of action: investing in mining projects, stockpiling critical minerals, protecting producers from market distortions and rebuilding the mining ecosystem through regulatory reform and workforce development. The overarching message is a shift from discussion to execution, with the United States seeking broad international participation to build resilient, secure and diversified critical mineral supply chains that support long-term global prosperity and security.
data.thread_title: US State Department Critical Minerals Meeting

data.content: Corridor. · In Argentina, the Company has earned a direct 51% interest in the Argentine company, Deseado Dorado S.A.S ("Deseado"), that owns the exploration licences that make up the El Pantano Project in Santa Cruz province. The Company has now moved into the Phase 2 of the JV, that will see it move to 100% ownership of Deseado upon investment of an additional US$2m, a large part of which will be spent on a 3,000 metre drill program which commenced at El Pantano in November and is expected to conclude in early 2026. First holes from the El Pantano drilling program confirm a low sulphidation epithermal mineral system. Whilst assays are still awaited, the Company is confident that it has achieved its general objective of proving the existence of a substantial mineral system.

data.author: bandit1
data.content: SOLG was sold for a song ( assuming it completes) due to Newmont and BHP providing irrevocable undertakings at a level which shocked most LTH’s including me. In the end the control premium was modest as the larger holders bent over. Our directors have very modest holdings in OMI ( last time I looked I had more than our Chairman and CEO combined) so I suspect they are keen to maintain control for a number of years to monetize what looks like an attractive portfolio of opportunities. We have few large blocks last time I looked which could  be persuaded by the offer of a ‘modest’ premium like 40% when the journey is really just starting. Never say never but highly unlikely IMO that an offer  for the whole will be tabled at this stage as it would probably have to be hostile and could be well defended. Much more likely is a JV on El P and Brad is probably just waiting for the PM markets to calm down a little to release the MRE on Pepas which should show very impressive economics for a relatively modest capital commitment. Perhaps the BOD have received interest on both El P and El Cedro and have been discussing the optimum outcome along with ensuring that the structure of any JV with Newmont or Agnico will not come back to bite us as is sadly seen with too much frequency these days. I expect news this week either way.

data.author: velma
data.content: I don't know, Northman.  I spent a bit of time yesterday rewatching the presentations/interviews from late last year ( https://www.orosur.ca/investors/presentations/). The discussion re El Cedro at mins 6-10 in the November interview ( https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=E_ZnaIec-jw) went over my head at the time, but now seems like a clear statement from Brad that his strategy for 2026 is to try and find a big project that will attract someone like Newmont. As he says, Pepas isn't that project, but they pursued it to get the market support to get the money for exploration, which is exactly what OMI received in the last big raise.  That's why the APTA timeline has dragged, because they no longer need that MRE to get the share price up, so it's not a priority.  El Cedro is looking like a Q2 drill target rather than Q1, what with the aeromag delays, but Brad does seem to think it could be a million-ouncer, and that's why it's getting prioritised.  El Pantano, one hopes, might fall into the same category, but I think they know less about it at the moment.

data.author: Gourd
data.content: A Mineral Resource Estimate (MRE) is a technical assessment that calculates the tonnage and grade of a mineral deposit based on geological data (drilling, sampling, modeling) to determine its economic potential. It defines the size and quality of a deposit, typically categorized by confidence level (Measured, Indicated, Inferred) to guide mining projects and investment decision. Bottom line is we are after "measured (& indicated)" which should convert to bookable reserves as soon as feasibility studies are completed and final investment decisions are made to commence mining. Paper value assigned to each ounce gets closer to true value as the uncertainty reduces. Hoping minimum 100-200kOz  measured at >4g/t  to support current share price anything higher in the indicated and inferred is upside. Drill spacing looks close enough for measured across all of the main ore zone. GLA.

data.author: velma
data.content: Sanguine, Brad was saying on 24 Jan ( https://x.com/OrosurM/status/2014982783693697145) that re El Pantano "we have enough now to be getting some sort of picture of what we are seeing there.  Needs to be pulled together into a coherent story."  He's been stressing since drilling began that the goal was only to get a sense of the geology, rather than target the best hits.  They've rejigged how the assays are being tested, seemingly because they were seeing both gold and silver, so it seems unlikely the results are bad, and it's been confirmed that they found the sort of banding they were looking for.  The neutral case is that no one's had time to sit down and do the analysis on what the assays mean, and that's why they've not been released.  The hard bullish case is that they're already in talks about a JV or sale and the other party wants the results sat on.  That seems less likely, but either way, it's just a waiting game.

A rough deadline is often considered better than no deadline at all, otherwise investors might panic. Even the best explorers fail to deliver on on tume most of the time. I dont understand why so many of you pay such close attention to deadlines

data.author: Legalwolf
data.content: Have to agree with the Doc on this one.  This is most definitely not the time to sell and think those that due will come to rue it.  We are only in January and there is SO much exciting newsflow to come here during the rest of the year, regardless of the macros.  There is every chance that new discoveries will be announced and we are on the verge of such at El P and North Pepas.  We also have guaranteed world class drilling results to come from APTA, which is about to be drilled to MRE. So whether the share price goes up, down, or sideways on the MRE, it will sure as hell be bouncing towards new highs on the newsflow to come in the weeks and months ahead.  Of that I am very confident.  OMI appears to have the midas touch when it comes to its projects.  Pepas is the smallest but perhaps tastiest, but the big hitters are yet to come.  Have to be here when those projects start to come home and for the biggest gains. Do not give your shares away too cheaply or prematurely.  Many have done already, and are no doubt regretting bailing out too early. 40p is a level we should all be relatively comfortable with and remain firmly sitting on those hands.  But we've told many this already and folk will do what comes most easily to them.  All good and GLA for whatever you do around the MRE!

data.title: Maiden Mineral Resource Estimate at Pepas
data.full_content:
10 Feb 2026 07:00
RNS Number : 2951S
Orosur Mining Inc
10 February 2026
Orosur Mining Inc.
('Orosur' or 'The Company')
Maiden Mineral Resource Estimate at Pepas, Anzá Project, Colombia
·
Maiden Mineral Resource Estimate at Pepas of 1.14 Mt at 5.46 g/t Au in Indicated classification for 201,000 ounces of contained gold.
·
Additional Inferred Mineral Resource of 0.19 Mt at 2.99 g/t Au for 18,000 ounces of contained gold.
London, February 10th 2026
.
Orosur Mining Inc.
("
Orosur
" or the "
Company
")
(TSXV/AIM:OMI)
, is pleased to announce the completion of a maiden Mineral Resource estimate ("MRE") for the Pepas deposit, at the Company's Anzá Project in Colombia.
The Anzá Project comprises a number of granted exploration titles and applications totalling roughly 330km2 within the Mid-Cauca gold belt, west of the city of Medellin, Antioquia state, Colombia. Orosur owns 100% of these titles and applications through two Colombian wholly owned subsidiary companies, Minera Anzá, and Minera Monte Aguila.
The Pepas gold deposit is located in the northern part of the Anzá project area and was discovered by the Company's previous JV partners in early 2022, but not advanced. When the Company reassumed 100% ownership of Anzá in November 2024, it commenced drilling immediately at Pepas with positive results, leading to the decision in June 2025 to focus drilling entirely at Pepas to allow estimation of a Mineral Resource as quickly as possible.
Orosur CEO Brad George commented:
"The Company's decision to focus its efforts on moving the Pepas deposit toward an MRE has been justified with this result. We will now immediately move Pepas into the economic study and permitting stage, while at the same time expanding our exploration effort to begin testing e other prospects within the Anzá project."
Figure 1. Anzá Project
Pepas Mineral Resource Estimate
A Mineral Resource Estimate ("MRE") has been completed for the Pepas deposit by international mineral consulting firm, Bara Consulting Limited, with an effective date of
16 January 2026
. The MRE was prepared in accordance with the 2019 Canadian Institute of Mining, Metallurgy and Petroleum ("CIM") Estimation of Mineral Resources & Mineral Reserves Best Practice Guidelines and 2014 CIM Definition Standards for Mineral Resources & Mineral Reserves and disclosed to National Instrument 43-101 ("NI 43-101"). Details of the MRE evaluation will be provided in a Technical Report prepared in accordance with NI 43-101 filed under the Company's SEDAR profile within 45 days of this release.
The Pepas Mineral Resource comprises an estimated 1.14 million tonnes at a grade of 5.46 g/t gold for 201,000 ounces of gold in the Indicated Mineral Resource category and 0.19 million tonnes at a grade of 2.99 g/t gold for 19,000 ounces of gold in the Inferred Mineral Resource category and assumes extraction via an open pit mining scenario. Mineral Resources are classified as Indicated and Inferred based on CIM Definition Standards.
The resource is entirely contained within an open pit shell, down to a vertical depth of approximately 100m, with mineralisation starting at surface. The MRE and pit shell have been generated using a gold price of US$3000/oz and a reporting cut-off grade of 0.92g/t Au.
Deposit

Contained Gold (ozs)

Table 1. Resource table, Pepas
1 Tonnages are rounded to the nearest 10,000t to reflect this as an estimate.
2 Metal content is rounded to the nearest 1,000ozs to reflect this as an estimate.
3 Mineral Resources are not Mineral Reserves and do not have demonstrated economic viability.
4 Mineral Resources are reported above a cut-off grade of 0.92 g/t Au within a conceptual pit shell
generated in support of reasonable prospects of eventual economic extraction (RPEEE) as per
CIM Estimation of Mineral Resources and Mineral Reserves Best Practise Guidelines prepared by
the CIM Mineral Resource and Mineral Reserve Committee and adopted by the CIM Council on
November 29, 2019 which incorporates gold price, payability, recovery, throughput, mining costs,
processing costs and transport cost assumptions which are considered reasonable at a conceptual level.
5 The conceptual pit shell has been generated using the following assumptions and parameters; throughput of 250ktpa, gold price
(USD$3,000), payability (99.5%), Au recovery (88.75%), ROM transport cost (USD$2.50/t)
processing costs (USD$60/t), G&A cost (USD$10/t) and mining costs (US$2.05/t, US$3.40/t and
USD$3.50/t for oxide, transitional and fresh material respectively)
6 The QP is not aware of any legal, permitting, title, taxation, socio-economic, marketing, political
environmental or other risk factors that might materially affect the estimate of Mineral Resources

data.author: Legalwolf
data.content: Okay, a few people have asked.  So this is how I "genuinely" feel about things right now: 1) We have an enviable and world class exploration portfolio, with district scale potential.  We are likely sitting on millions of ounces across the portfolio. 2) But it's no good having these projects unless you have the cash (and skill/luck) to drill them and make discoveries. 3) Here, OMI has two key sources of cash.  The first is the existing kitty of £13 million.  The second is this Pepas deposit - albeit a few years away yet from going into production. 4) The £13 million we already have is MORE THAN sufficient for OMI to make a second and much larger scale discovery.  So we don't actually need the Pepas cash to "make" a second discovery and generate that upside.  That's been taken care of already with the fund raises. 5) The Pepas cash WILL, however, allow OMI to take a second discovery into production AND fund all future exploration costs across the portfolio. 6) At the point any second project goes into production, the cash generated from it will likely dwarf the cash being generated by this Pepas deposit.  Pepas will only be the flag bearer for as long as it takes to get the much larger second project into production.  The second producing project will actually be the big prize here. (An exception to this might be if we go onto discover more Pepas's, such that Pepas itself actually grows into the large scale flag bearing production project - could easily happen!) THIS is the sequence of compelling fundamentals that have caused me to have a large position in OMI and have a LTH in mind.  In order for this dream company making scenario to happen, the following needed/needs to happen: 1) Pepas is capable of generating enough cash to fund the second project.  On today's MRE, this has been FULLY accomplished.  So this is a clear ✔. 2) Pepas is also capable of generating enough cash to fund future exploration. data.author: JackB14
data.content: Orosur Mining's (OMI) Pepas prospect at the Anzá project has a maiden mineral resource estimate of approximately 219,000 ounces (201,000 oz indicated at 5.46 g/t Au and 18,000 oz inferred at 2.99 g/t Au). Based on conceptual economic modeling for a shallow, high-grade open-pit operation utilizing third-party toll processing, the initial capex is estimated at around US$16 million. This would equate to roughly $67-80 per ounce of recoverable gold over the life of mine (assuming 72% extraction rate yielding ~238,000 oz from a similar-sized resource). Compared to global benchmarks, this capex intensity is exceptionally low. Typical gold development projects range from $200-500+ per ounce (e.g., large-scale operations like Barrick's Fourmile at ~$100-280/oz over reserves, or mid-tier Canadian projects at ~$250/oz annual production equivalent), with even optimized small-scale builds rarely dipping below $100/oz. Factors like Pepas' near-surface mineralization, simple metallurgy (88-90% recovery), low mining costs ($2-3.50/t), and off-site processing enable this minimal upfront spend, positioning it among the world's lowest for near-term producers. Not all mines are the same....

data.author: Yelacoirii
data.content: Back of the envelope figures. Gold Price $5k. Might be too high. AISC: $1500. Might be too low. Total oz: 220,000. (You'd expect them to find more.) Revenue: $1.1 billion. Costs: $330m. Gross Profit: $770m. Taxes, royalties etc. Assume 25%. Total net profit: $575m Exchange rate at 1.37 dollars to £. £420m. NPV to account for 10-12 years. Depends on your discount rate, but I'd guess about £180m. You'd then discount to this because the mine isn't there producing gold as expected, but is currently years away. Very subjective. Anywhere from maybe £50-100m. Which isn't too far from where we are. I think the story that may get lost in all this though is that Pepas is still special. It is in scope for Omi to build it and profit from. If the company was earning £40m a year there's massive scope for exploration and project development. Never say never I guess - but while Brad can chase his white whale, these will never be mined by Omi. I think even APTA is fundamentally out of scope. The upfront cost will be too high, so you'd have to sell the project to someone, potentially at a significant discount. You'd hope perhaps we are heading towards a bull market with lots of M&A, but its not guaranteed. My concern is that bringing this to production is going to be quite slow and boring. Brad has run off to Brazil and Nigeria when previously bored. In that case though he had nothing to do with Newmont and Agnico controlling things. They need to get this through permitting and then start looking for Pepas II, III, IV etc. Or we can hope to find the motherlode in Argentina and get bought out.

data.author: Legalwolf
data.content: Hi Doc - a lot will depend on exactly when those catalysts land.  Some of the relevant factors might be: 1) What is gold doing at the time the particular catalyst lands? 2) What is the general market doing? 3) What is OMI's share price doing - consolidating, retracing or already on the move up?  (FOMO, sell on news, etc) 4) Has there already been another catalyst recently delivered to the market? 5) What other catalysts or news is pending at that time? There's no doubt that a new discovery at Pepas North will be a biggie.  But I also think that getting "Pepas style" results at APTA will move the share price needle, especially if they land in favourable market conditions.  It goes without saying that the same applies at El Cedro (huge project).  As for El P, we will need to wait to see what they have already found, and how close they are to a major discovery there, when they will target the discovery, as well as what JV interest they get. But plenty of fantastic share price drivers here, which is what makes this a very exciting and compelling share.  If the Pepas MRE can take us and provide us with a higher floor (whether much higher or slightly higher), then it sets us up very nicely for one or more of the multiple potential catalysts that we have coming up here to then drive us up to the next level.  That's the investment case here and it's just a case of letting it play out over the coming months and quarters.  Let's hope we get off to a cracking start with the Pepas MRE.  All imo and GLA

data.author: OrangeMoon
data.content: The solid investment case here is Pepas Deposit — a true golden nugget. High-grade (from surface), low-tonnage potential that should — all going well — return multiples of the current market cap. This will probably take 2–3 years to come to fruition and start delivering those returns. It's a great long-term investment case in my opinion. I think the institutional investors agree. It's often stated that "where there is gold, there is more"… and as Brad has said, "we've only just scratched the surface… we haven't even begun to look deep." Initially, I invested here because of Pepas and the potential for another deposit of this type. I haven't lost any optimism about the prospect of finding Pepas North — in fact, I've only grown more confident. So remember: regardless of the distractions caused by short-term price fluctuations (whether in the metals market or OMI's share price) and the emotions they may trigger for investors watching the hourly/daily/weekly charts, our deposits have been forming over millions of years… and just like me, they aren't going anywhere.

data.author: middleEastMoney
data.content: This applies to OMI I think. “Not exactly. Broadly speaking, as a gold prospect generator, that view might hold — but let me explain, because there are several factors at work. At the point where true value is first created — the “HAD005 moment”, when you actually discover gold — the share price is leveraged partly to the gold price and partly to market perception and expectations. At that stage, the share price reflects value in the ground, which itself depends on multiple new variables: size and grade how big the system is location and, critically, the realistic probability of becoming an economic mine Many projects fail. Many mines fail. Above all, however, the share price reflects the market’s confidence in management’s ability to deliver a mine or project. That’s precisely why GGP’s share price fell so hard while De Grey’s didn’t fall as badly in 2022. Once you become a gold producer, everything changes. The key difference is that you can now leverage your balance sheet and cash flow against both operational performance and the gold price. You’re no longer forced to rely on debt. You can: fund project development internally, accelerate projects , discover additional ounces, consolidate assets , acquire complementary projects In short, production gives you control — and that’s where sustained value creation really begins. GGP's SP exploded once it became clear GGP management had control. A wise and called Rusty Delroy once said 8 or 9 /10ths of any junior miner or developers value /market cap is essentially the market's confidence that they will deliver. This is easily demonstrated by Solgold was recently sold for £850m whereas GGP is today worth some £4.5bn and pumping out $ billions in revenue. But yet solgold had over 24moz of gold - versus GGPs 3 moz. Funny that don't you think. Serious investors (ie the market) felt Solg management were un-investable.”
data.thread_title: From GGP board, posted by Element 1, respected poster

data.author: TheUmber
data.content: Here's the link and a summary from today's US State Department critical minerals meeting: state . gov/releases/office-of-the-spokesperson/2026/02/opening-remarks-of-the-critical-minerals-ministerial/  (remove spaces) The U.S. administration argues that critical mineral markets are distorted by overproduction, price volatility and non-market practices that discourage long-term investment. This has caused mining and processing projects worldwide to stall or fail, weakening supply chain resilience and threatening economic and security interests. The administration views this as a shared international problem that requires coordinated action among allies. To address this, the United States outlines a strategy centred on reindustrialisation, securing end-to-end supply chains and rebuilding domestic mining and processing capacity. Measures include large-scale public financing, direct investment in mining and processing projects, accelerated permitting, creation of strategic mineral stockpiles and protection of domestic producers from unfair price competition. A key proposal is the creation of a preferential critical minerals trade zone among allied countries, featuring enforceable price floors and coordinated trade measures to stabilise markets, support investment and prevent market flooding. The goal is to diversify global supply, ensure predictable pricing and strengthen partner economies while reducing dependence on concentrated or unreliable sources. Japan strongly supports these objectives, highlighting its own efforts to diversify supply, invest upstream and downstream and enhance economic security through legislation, public-private financing and international cooperation. Japan stresses that resilience can only be achieved collectively and welcomes new forums for coordination such as FORGE. U.S. officials further outline four pillars of action: investing in mining projects, stockpiling critical minerals, protecting producers from market distortions and rebuilding the mining ecosystem through regulatory reform and workforce development. The overarching message is a shift from discussion to execution, with the United States seeking broad international participation to build resilient, secure and diversified critical mineral supply chains that support long-term global prosperity and security.
data.thread_title: US State Department Critical Minerals Meeting

data.content: Corridor. · In Argentina, the Company has earned a direct 51% interest in the Argentine company, Deseado Dorado S.A.S ("Deseado"), that owns the exploration licences that make up the El Pantano Project in Santa Cruz province. The Company has now moved into the Phase 2 of the JV, that will see it move to 100% ownership of Deseado upon investment of an additional US$2m, a large part of which will be spent on a 3,000 metre drill program which commenced at El Pantano in November and is expected to conclude in early 2026. First holes from the El Pantano drilling program confirm a low sulphidation epithermal mineral system. Whilst assays are still awaited, the Company is confident that it has achieved its general objective of proving the existence of a substantial mineral system.

data.author: bandit1
data.content: SOLG was sold for a song ( assuming it completes) due to Newmont and BHP providing irrevocable undertakings at a level which shocked most LTH’s including me. In the end the control premium was modest as the larger holders bent over. Our directors have very modest holdings in OMI ( last time I looked I had more than our Chairman and CEO combined) so I suspect they are keen to maintain control for a number of years to monetize what looks like an attractive portfolio of opportunities. We have few large blocks last time I looked which could  be persuaded by the offer of a ‘modest’ premium like 40% when the journey is really just starting. Never say never but highly unlikely IMO that an offer  for the whole will be tabled at this stage as it would probably have to be hostile and could be well defended. Much more likely is a JV on El P and Brad is probably just waiting for the PM markets to calm down a little to release the MRE on Pepas which should show very impressive economics for a relatively modest capital commitment. Perhaps the BOD have received interest on both El P and El Cedro and have been discussing the optimum outcome along with ensuring that the structure of any JV with Newmont or Agnico will not come back to bite us as is sadly seen with too much frequency these days. I expect news this week either way.

data.author: velma
data.content: I don't know, Northman.  I spent a bit of time yesterday rewatching the presentations/interviews from late last year ( https://www.orosur.ca/investors/presentations/). The discussion re El Cedro at mins 6-10 in the November interview ( https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=E_ZnaIec-jw) went over my head at the time, but now seems like a clear statement from Brad that his strategy for 2026 is to try and find a big project that will attract someone like Newmont. As he says, Pepas isn't that project, but they pursued it to get the market support to get the money for exploration, which is exactly what OMI received in the last big raise.  That's why the APTA timeline has dragged, because they no longer need that MRE to get the share price up, so it's not a priority.  El Cedro is looking like a Q2 drill target rather than Q1, what with the aeromag delays, but Brad does seem to think it could be a million-ouncer, and that's why it's getting prioritised.  El Pantano, one hopes, might fall into the same category, but I think they know less about it at the moment.

data.author: Gourd
data.content: A Mineral Resource Estimate (MRE) is a technical assessment that calculates the tonnage and grade of a mineral deposit based on geological data (drilling, sampling, modeling) to determine its economic potential. It defines the size and quality of a deposit, typically categorized by confidence level (Measured, Indicated, Inferred) to guide mining projects and investment decision. Bottom line is we are after "measured (& indicated)" which should convert to bookable reserves as soon as feasibility studies are completed and final investment decisions are made to commence mining. Paper value assigned to each ounce gets closer to true value as the uncertainty reduces. Hoping minimum 100-200kOz  measured at >4g/t  to support current share price anything higher in the indicated and inferred is upside. Drill spacing looks close enough for measured across all of the main ore zone. GLA.

data.author: velma
data.content: Sanguine, Brad was saying on 24 Jan ( https://x.com/OrosurM/status/2014982783693697145) that re El Pantano "we have enough now to be getting some sort of picture of what we are seeing there.  Needs to be pulled together into a coherent story."  He's been stressing since drilling began that the goal was only to get a sense of the geology, rather than target the best hits.  They've rejigged how the assays are being tested, seemingly because they were seeing both gold and silver, so it seems unlikely the results are bad, and it's been confirmed that they found the sort of banding they were looking for.  The neutral case is that no one's had time to sit down and do the analysis on what the assays mean, and that's why they've not been released.  The hard bullish case is that they're already in talks about a JV or sale and the other party wants the results sat on.  That seems less likely, but either way, it's just a waiting game.

data.author: Legalwolf
data.content: Have to agree with the Doc on this one.  This is most definitely not the time to sell and think those that due will come to rue it.  We are only in January and there is SO much exciting newsflow to come here during the rest of the year, regardless of the macros.  There is every chance that new discoveries will be announced and we are on the verge of such at El P and North Pepas.  We also have guaranteed world class drilling results to come from APTA, which is about to be drilled to MRE. So whether the share price goes up, down, or sideways on the MRE, it will sure as hell be bouncing towards new highs on the newsflow to come in the weeks and months ahead.  Of that I am very confident.  OMI appears to have the midas touch when it comes to its projects.  Pepas is the smallest but perhaps tastiest, but the big hitters are yet to come.  Have to be here when those projects start to come home and for the biggest gains. Do not give your shares away too cheaply or prematurely.  Many have done already, and are no doubt regretting bailing out too early. 40p is a level we should all be relatively comfortable with and remain firmly sitting on those hands.  But we've told many this already and folk will do what comes most easily to them.  All good and GLA for whatever you do around the MRE!

data.author: Legalwolf
data.content: No solidarity in this game - just pure Wolf of Wall Street stuff.  I keep saying that you can't change bb, and have to roll with punches and factor such behaviour and antics into your game plan and strategy.  There's absolutely nothing you can do when there's a shake on or sell on news events in terms of folk coming on here and spreading fud and fear.  This is part of the game, and part of their game plan.  Or in some cases, they just like to wind up for the fun of it. Similarly, you can't help the obvious rampers who shoot for the moon at every positive tick on the chart or piece of news.  If you are on the bb long enough, you are able to identify for yourself who falls into what category.  Who you think has credibility and is worth listening to, whether they are bullish or bearish.  Who are the trolls, mischief makers and fudsters.  Can't do much about them though other than to filter, not engage and/or warn others. Being a LTH on AIM is a real gruel at times.  You will experience some real highs and lows on the way, and all sorts of antics. Ultimately, the ONLY thing that will help you, and save you, is to have chosen the right stock, at the right time, in the first place.  If you made the right call, then you will still take some hits along the way, but should live to celebrate the tale.

data.author: Jings
data.content: As per my post yesterday, I think the drop over the past couple of days has been well over done/manufacturer. Brad obviously came out fighting this morning on X, which is nice to see, however I believe his language may have contributed to some further drift today. i.e. Pepas "should become clearer in a month or two",  "Anza in a week or two once we get the logistics sorted"," Drilling at El Pantano should end in a few weeks" (which suggests we will get nothing till all the drilling is done/analysed)., "aero mag starting at El Cedro and APTA as soon as the crew finishes their work for our neighbours Royal Road." - Given BG's records of not sticking to forecast time scales, I am wondering  a lot of day  trader types who may have hung about for the bounce, thought - nothing going on here for at least a couple of months,  I will take my cash elsewhere for the time being. .If this is indeed the case and we hear nothing for several weeks, I am scared we may drift further. As I said yesterday I am a LTH so a month or two here or there does affect me in the long run, but to have lost 3 'paper' bags in the last week, the thought of further drift is very frustrating. Think we should ban BG from making timescale/MRE predictions! :-)

data.author: Legalwolf
data.content: Taken from the Candian bb: Pepas MRE: indicated 1.14 million ton, 5.46g/t Au, contained gold 201,000 oz.  open pit throughput of 250ktpa, gold price (USD$3,000), payability (99.5%). Au recovery (88.75%) Transport cost (USD$2.50/t) Processing costs (USD$60/t), G&A cost (USD$10/t) and Mining costs (US$2.05/t, US$3.40/t and USD$3.50/t for oxide, transitional and fresh material respectively). Cost: 2.5 + 60 + 10 + 3.5 = $76/t 250ktpa = 250,000/365 = 685t/day 685t/d x $76/t = $52,060/d Production: 685 t/d x 5.46g/t x 88.75% = 3,319 g/d = 117 oz/d 117oz/d x $4,000/oz = $468,000/d Profit: 468,000 - 52,000 = $416,000/d MONTHLY PROFIT = $12 million. ANNUAL PROFIT = $120 million This is based only on $3000 gold folks!  Imagine the upside if gold is at $4k or $5k or $6k when Pepas goes into production.  What about the upside from any new discoveries. This a great share, with CRAZY potential.  It now has a commercial production project which is going to to be a ridiculous cash cow as the above figures demonstrates.  The company and its fundamentals just got a whole lot stronger and the market will HAVE TO catch up to the reality once it appreciates what has just happened.

data.content: There's been a lot of ramping and deramping nonsense posted today and yesterday. Felt compelled to stop lurking and pipe up to seek clarity. So could someone please factually restate the case for OMI over the next 12 months? data.author: Legalwolf
data.content: Okay, a few people have asked.  So this is how I "genuinely" feel about things right now: 1) We have an enviable and world class exploration portfolio, with district scale potential.  We are likely sitting on millions of ounces across the portfolio. 2) But it's no good having these projects unless you have the cash (and skill/luck) to drill them and make discoveries. 3) Here, OMI has two key sources of cash.  The first is the existing kitty of £13 million.  The second is this Pepas deposit - albeit a few years away yet from going into production. 4) The £13 million we already have is MORE THAN sufficient for OMI to make a second and much larger scale discovery.  So we don't actually need the Pepas cash to "make" a second discovery and generate that upside.  That's been taken care of already with the fund raises. 5) The Pepas cash WILL, however, allow OMI to take a second discovery into production AND fund all future exploration costs across the portfolio. 6) At the point any second project goes into production, the cash generated from it will likely dwarf the cash being generated by this Pepas deposit.  Pepas will only be the flag bearer for as long as it takes to get the much larger second project into production.  The second producing project will actually be the big prize here. (An exception to this might be if we go onto discover more Pepas's, such that Pepas itself actually grows into the large scale flag bearing production project - could easily happen!) THIS is the sequence of compelling fundamentals that have caused me to have a large position in OMI and have a LTH in mind.  In order for this dream company making scenario to happen, the following needed/needs to happen: 1) Pepas is capable of generating enough cash to fund the second project.  On today's MRE, this has been FULLY accomplished.  So this is a clear ✔. 2) Pepas is also capable of generating enough cash to fund future exploration.  On today's MRE, this has been FULLY accomplished.  So this is a clear ✔. 3) Whilst Pepas is being prepared for production, OMI makes a second commercial discovery.  Some would argue that this is also a ✔ based on APTA, but let's call this an X for now.   Will this second discovery be APTA, North Pepas, El P, El C or LV?  This remains to be seen! So overall how do I feel about the MRE? - whilst it's lower than the baseline 250koz I wanted, it's only short by 30koz.  This shortfall is completely irrelevant in the overall scheme of things.  Because on today's RNS, its very much MISSION ACCOMPLISHED in terms of what we needed from this initial Pepas deposit!  Which means it's GAME VERY MUCH ON AND DREAM VERY MUCH ALIVE so far as I am concerned.  Easy and big money to be made here from 25p in the coming weeks and months!  All imo and dyor

data.author: JackB14
data.content: Orosur Mining's (OMI) Pepas prospect at the Anzá project has a maiden mineral resource estimate of approximately 219,000 ounces (201,000 oz indicated at 5.46 g/t Au and 18,000 oz inferred at 2.99 g/t Au). Based on conceptual economic modeling for a shallow, high-grade open-pit operation utilizing third-party toll processing, the initial capex is estimated at around US$16 million. This would equate to roughly $67-80 per ounce of recoverable gold over the life of mine (assuming 72% extraction rate yielding ~238,000 oz from a similar-sized resource). Compared to global benchmarks, this capex intensity is exceptionally low. Typical gold development projects range from $200-500+ per ounce (e.g., large-scale operations like Barrick's Fourmile at ~$100-280/oz over reserves, or mid-tier Canadian projects at ~$250/oz annual production equivalent), with even optimized small-scale builds rarely dipping below $100/oz. Factors like Pepas' near-surface mineralization, simple metallurgy (88-90% recovery), low mining costs ($2-3.50/t), and off-site processing enable this minimal upfront spend, positioning it among the world's lowest for near-term producers. Not all mines are the same....

data.author: Yelacoirii
data.content: Back of the envelope figures. Gold Price $5k. Might be too high. AISC: $1500. Might be too low. Total oz: 220,000. (You'd expect them to find more.) Revenue: $1.1 billion. Costs: $330m. Gross Profit: $770m. Taxes, royalties etc. Assume 25%. Total net profit: $575m Exchange rate at 1.37 dollars to £. £420m. NPV to account for 10-12 years. Depends on your discount rate, but I'd guess about £180m. You'd then discount to this because the mine isn't there producing gold as expected, but is currently years away. Very subjective. Anywhere from maybe £50-100m. Which isn't too far from where we are. I think the story that may get lost in all this though is that Pepas is still special. It is in scope for Omi to build it and profit from. If the company was earning £40m a year there's massive scope for exploration and project development. Never say never I guess - but while Brad can chase his white whale, these will never be mined by Omi. I think even APTA is fundamentally out of scope. The upfront cost will be too high, so you'd have to sell the project to someone, potentially at a significant discount. You'd hope perhaps we are heading towards a bull market with lots of M&A, but its not guaranteed. My concern is that bringing this to production is going to be quite slow and boring. Brad has run off to Brazil and Nigeria when previously bored. In that case though he had nothing to do with Newmont and Agnico controlling things. They need to get this through permitting and then start looking for Pepas II, III, IV etc. Or we can hope to find the motherlode in Argentina and get bought out.

data.author: Legalwolf
data.content: Hi Doc - a lot will depend on exactly when those catalysts land.  Some of the relevant factors might be: 1) What is gold doing at the time the particular catalyst lands? 2) What is the general market doing? 3) What is OMI's share price doing - consolidating, retracing or already on the move up?  (FOMO, sell on news, etc) 4) Has there already been another catalyst recently delivered to the market? 5) What other catalysts or news is pending at that time? There's no doubt that a new discovery at Pepas North will be a biggie.  But I also think that getting "Pepas style" results at APTA will move the share price needle, especially if they land in favourable market conditions.  It goes without saying that the same applies at El Cedro (huge project).  As for El P, we will need to wait to see what they have already found, and how close they are to a major discovery there, when they will target the discovery, as well as what JV interest they get. But plenty of fantastic share price drivers here, which is what makes this a very exciting and compelling share.  If the Pepas MRE can take us and provide us with a higher floor (whether much higher or slightly higher), then it sets us up very nicely for one or more of the multiple potential catalysts that we have coming up here to then drive us up to the next level.  That's the investment case here and it's just a case of letting it play out over the coming months and quarters.  Let's hope we get off to a cracking start with the Pepas MRE.  All imo and GLA

data.author: OrangeMoon
data.content: The solid investment case here is Pepas Deposit — a true golden nugget. High-grade (from surface), low-tonnage potential that should — all going well — return multiples of the current market cap. This will probably take 2–3 years to come to fruition and start delivering those returns. It's a great long-term investment case in my opinion. I think the institutional investors agree. It's often stated that "where there is gold, there is more"… and as Brad has said, "we've only just scratched the surface… we haven't even begun to look deep." Initially, I invested here because of Pepas and the potential for another deposit of this type. I haven't lost any optimism about the prospect of finding Pepas North — in fact, I've only grown more confident. So remember: regardless of the distractions caused by short-term price fluctuations (whether in the metals market or OMI's share price) and the emotions they may trigger for investors watching the hourly/daily/weekly charts, our deposits have been forming over millions of years… and just like me, they aren't going anywhere.

data.author: middleEastMoney
data.content: This applies to OMI I think. “Not exactly. Broadly speaking, as a gold prospect generator, that view might hold — but let me explain, because there are several factors at work. At the point where true value is first created — the “HAD005 moment”, when you actually discover gold — the share price is leveraged partly to the gold price and partly to market perception and expectations. At that stage, the share price reflects value in the ground, which itself depends on multiple new variables: size and grade how big the system is location and, critically, the realistic probability of becoming an economic mine Many projects fail. Many mines fail. Above all, however, the share price reflects the market’s confidence in management’s ability to deliver a mine or project. That’s precisely why GGP’s share price fell so hard while De Grey’s didn’t fall as badly in 2022. Once you become a gold producer, everything changes. The key difference is that you can now leverage your balance sheet and cash flow against both operational performance and the gold price. You’re no longer forced to rely on debt. You can: fund project development internally, accelerate projects , discover additional ounces, consolidate assets , acquire complementary projects In short, production gives you control — and that’s where sustained value creation really begins. GGP's SP exploded once it became clear GGP management had control. A wise and called Rusty Delroy once said 8 or 9 /10ths of any junior miner or developers value /market cap is essentially the market's confidence that they will deliver. This is easily demonstrated by Solgold was recently sold for £850m whereas GGP is today worth some £4.5bn and pumping out $ billions in revenue. But yet solgold had over 24moz of gold - versus GGPs 3 moz. Funny that don't you think. Serious investors (ie the market) felt Solg management were un-investable.”
data.thread_title: From GGP board, posted by Element 1, respected poster

data.author: TheUmber
data.content: Here's the link and a summary from today's US State Department critical minerals meeting: state . gov/releases/office-of-the-spokesperson/2026/02/opening-remarks-of-the-critical-minerals-ministerial/  (remove spaces) The U.S. administration argues that critical mineral markets are distorted by overproduction, price volatility and non-market practices that discourage long-term investment. This has caused mining and processing projects worldwide to stall or fail, weakening supply chain resilience and threatening economic and security interests. The administration views this as a shared international problem that requires coordinated action among allies. To address this, the United States outlines a strategy centred on reindustrialisation, securing end-to-end supply chains and rebuilding domestic mining and processing capacity. Measures include large-scale public financing, direct investment in mining and processing projects, accelerated permitting, creation of strategic mineral stockpiles and protection of domestic producers from unfair price competition. A key proposal is the creation of a preferential critical minerals trade zone among allied countries, featuring enforceable price floors and coordinated trade measures to stabilise markets, support investment and prevent market flooding. The goal is to diversify global supply, ensure predictable pricing and strengthen partner economies while reducing dependence on concentrated or unreliable sources. Japan strongly supports these objectives, highlighting its own efforts to diversify supply, invest upstream and downstream and enhance economic security through legislation, public-private financing and international cooperation. Japan stresses that resilience can only be achieved collectively and welcomes new forums for coordination such as FORGE. U.S. officials further outline four pillars of action: investing in mining projects, stockpiling critical minerals, protecting producers from market distortions and rebuilding the mining ecosystem through regulatory reform and workforce development. The overarching message is a shift from discussion to execution, with the United States seeking broad international participation to build resilient, secure and diversified critical mineral supply chains that support long-term global prosperity and security.
data.thread_title: US State Department Critical Minerals Meeting

data.author: napthman1
data.content: Corridor. · In Argentina, the Company has earned a direct 51% interest in the Argentine company, Deseado Dorado S.A.S ("Deseado"), that owns the exploration licences that make up the El Pantano Project in Santa Cruz province. The Company has now moved into the Phase 2 of the JV, that will see it move to 100% ownership of Deseado upon investment of an additional US$2m, a large part of which will be spent on a 3,000 metre drill program which commenced at El Pantano in November and is expected to conclude in early 2026. First holes from the El Pantano drilling program confirm a low sulphidation epithermal mineral system. data.author: bandit1
data.content: SOLG was sold for a song ( assuming it completes) due to Newmont and BHP providing irrevocable undertakings at a level which shocked most LTH’s including me. In the end the control premium was modest as the larger holders bent over. Our directors have very modest holdings in OMI ( last time I looked I had more than our Chairman and CEO combined) so I suspect they are keen to maintain control for a number of years to monetize what looks like an attractive portfolio of opportunities. We have few large blocks last time I looked which could  be persuaded by the offer of a ‘modest’ premium like 40% when the journey is really just starting. Never say never but highly unlikely IMO that an offer  for the whole will be tabled at this stage as it would probably have to be hostile and could be well defended. Much more likely is a JV on El P and Brad is probably just waiting for the PM markets to calm down a little to release the MRE on Pepas which should show very impressive economics for a relatively modest capital commitment. Perhaps the BOD have received interest on both El P and El Cedro and have been discussing the optimum outcome along with ensuring that the structure of any JV with Newmont or Agnico will not come back to bite us as is sadly seen with too much frequency these days. I expect news this week either way.

data.author: velma
data.content: I don't know, Northman.  I spent a bit of time yesterday rewatching the presentations/interviews from late last year ( https://www.orosur.ca/investors/presentations/). The discussion re El Cedro at mins 6-10 in the November interview ( https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=E_ZnaIec-jw) went over my head at the time, but now seems like a clear statement from Brad that his strategy for 2026 is to try and find a big project that will attract someone like Newmont. As he says, Pepas isn't that project, but they pursued it to get the market support to get the money for exploration, which is exactly what OMI received in the last big raise.  That's why the APTA timeline has dragged, because they no longer need that MRE to get the share price up, so it's not a priority.  El Cedro is looking like a Q2 drill target rather than Q1, what with the aeromag delays, but Brad does seem to think it could be a million-ouncer, and that's why it's getting prioritised.  El Pantano, one hopes, might fall into the same category, but I think they know less about it at the moment.

data.author: Gourd
data.content: A Mineral Resource Estimate (MRE) is a technical assessment that calculates the tonnage and grade of a mineral deposit based on geological data (drilling, sampling, modeling) to determine its economic potential. It defines the size and quality of a deposit, typically categorized by confidence level (Measured, Indicated, Inferred) to guide mining projects and investment decision. Bottom line is we are after "measured (& indicated)" which should convert to bookable reserves as soon as feasibility studies are completed and final investment decisions are made to commence mining. Paper value assigned to each ounce gets closer to true value as the uncertainty reduces. Hoping minimum 100-200kOz  measured at >4g/t  to support current share price anything higher in the indicated and inferred is upside. Drill spacing looks close enough for measured across all of the main ore zone. GLA.

data.author: velma
data.content: Sanguine, Brad was saying on 24 Jan ( https://x.com/OrosurM/status/2014982783693697145) that re El Pantano "we have enough now to be getting some sort of picture of what we are seeing there.  Needs to be pulled together into a coherent story."  He's been stressing since drilling began that the goal was only to get a sense of the geology, rather than target the best hits.  They've rejigged how the assays are being tested, seemingly because they were seeing both gold and silver, so it seems unlikely the results are bad, and it's been confirmed that they found the sort of banding they were looking for.  The neutral case is that no one's had time to sit down and do the analysis on what the assays mean, and that's why they've not been released.  The hard bullish case is that they're already in talks about a JV or sale and the other party wants the results sat on.  That seems less likely, but either way, it's just a waiting game.

data.author: Kemot
data.content: I’ve been invested in explorers since 2018, and if there’s one rule of thumb, it’s that deadlines get missed over and over. I’ve heard that companies often provide timelines by essentially guessing the timeframe, because in many cases it’s impossible to know how long things will take. A rough deadline is often considered better than no deadline at all, otherwise investors might panic. Even the best explorers fail to deliver on on tume most of the time. I dont understand why so many of you pay such close attention to deadlines

data.author: Legalwolf
data.content: Have to agree with the Doc on this one.  This is most definitely not the time to sell and think those that due will come to rue it.  We are only in January and there is SO much exciting newsflow to come here during the rest of the year, regardless of the macros.  There is every chance that new discoveries will be announced and we are on the verge of such at El P and North Pepas.  We also have guaranteed world class drilling results to come from APTA, which is about to be drilled to MRE. So whether the share price goes up, down, or sideways on the MRE, it will sure as hell be bouncing towards new highs on the newsflow to come in the weeks and months ahead.  Of that I am very confident.  OMI appears to have the midas touch when it comes to its projects.  Pepas is the smallest but perhaps tastiest, but the big hitters are yet to come.  Have to be here when those projects start to come home and for the biggest gains. Do not give your shares away too cheaply or prematurely.  Many have done already, and are no doubt regretting bailing out too early. 40p is a level we should all be relatively comfortable with and remain firmly sitting on those hands.  But we've told many this already and folk will do what comes most easily to them.  All good and GLA for whatever you do around the MRE!
